textline.text: 393 S. Dewey Ave.
Cedar City, UT 84720
Andrew D. Van Alstyne
Curriculum Vitae
September 2015
Assistant Professor
Department of History, Sociology, and Anthropology
Southern Utah University
351 West University Boulevard, CN 225
Cedar City, UT 84720
E-mail: andrewvanalstyne@suu.edu
Education:
andrew.vanalstyne@gmail.com
Ph.D. Sociology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI
Dissertation: From Social Movements to Non-Governmental Organizations:
Civil Society and Local Environmental Governance Under Fordism and
Neoliberalism
B.A. Sociology/English, St. Lawrence University, Canton, NY
magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa
M.A. Sociology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI
Employment History
Assistant Professor of Sociology, Southern Utah University (2013-Present)
Graduate Student Instructor, University of Michigan (2002-2010)
Research and Teaching Interests:
Environmental Sociology
Race and Ethnicity
Social Movements
Urban Sociology
Social Theory
Qualitative and Comparative
Historical Research Methods
Publications
“The Neoliberal Turn in Environmental Governance in the Detroit River Area of Concern.”
“The United Auto Workers and the Emergence of Labor Environmentalism.” WorkingUSA:
The Journal of Labor and Society. Forthcoming
“Freedom,” in Collateral Language: A User’s Guide to America’s New War, eds. John
Collins and Ross Glover. New York: New York University Press. 2002.
Book Reviews
Review of David J. Hess. Good Green Jobs in a Global Economy: Making and Keeping New
Industries in the United States. In Social Forces, April 8, 2014.
Review of Al Gedicks. Resource Rebels: Native Challenges to Mining and Oil Corporations.
In Society and Natural Resources. 15. 2002. pp 862-4.
Funding
Co-PI. . “Understanding Public Attitudes toward Water Shortages and Water Pricing in
Utah.” iUtah Research Catalyst Grant, 2015. $19,981.
Faculty Scholarly Support Fund, Southern Utah University, 2014, 2015
Conference Grants, Rackham Graduate School, University of Michigan, 2003-2005, 2010,
Research Grant, Rackham Graduate School, University of Michigan, 2011-12
Research Experience
Qualitative Research Consultant, Ford Motor Company, Dearborn, MI, 2009
Designed survey instrument for project focused on designing driver interface for
alternative powered vehicles
Trained research team
Analyzed data and synthesized results
Operationalized key concepts into instrument design
Research Assistant, Global Corporations and Human Well-Being, 2005
University of Michigan Ross Business School,
Principal Investigators, Gerald David, Marina Whitman, and Mayer Zald
Authored Paper “Global Social Movements and Global Corporate Social
Responsibility”
Trained and managed interview team for Pilot TSA project
Field Manager/Interview Team Leader, PA Consulting, 2001
Presentations
2015. “Green Lawns in the Desert: Water Scarcity in Southern Utah.” Paper presented at the
annual meetings of the American Sociological Association, Chicago.
2014. “Social Movements, NGOs, and Environmental Governance in the Detroit River Area
of Concern.” Paper presented at the annual meetings of the Pacific Sociological Association,
Portland, OR.
2014. “Gender and Leadership in the Environmental Movement.” Paper presented at the
Leadership and Empowerment Across Generations conference, Southern Utah University.
2012. “Shifting Local Environmental Governance: From Fordism to Neo-liberalism.” Paper
presented at the annual meetings of the American Sociological Association, Denver.
2010. “Assessing the Role of Public Participation in Environmental Remediation.”
Paper presented at the annual meetings of the American Sociological Association, Atlanta.
2005. “Examining Organized Labor and Environmentalism: The Case of the United Auto
Workers (UAW).” Paper presented at the annual meetings of the American Sociological
Association, Philadelphia.
2004. “The Two Logics of Environmental Action.” Paper presented at the annual meetings of
the American Sociological Association, San Francisco.
2003. “When Blue is Green: Rethinking the Labor-Environment Dichotomy.” Paper
presented at the annual meetings of the American Sociological Association, Atlanta.
Professional Activities and Service
American Sociological Association
Section on Environment, Technology, and Society
Sociology Graduate Students Organization,
Member 2003-present
Listserv Manager 2003- present
Co-Chair, 2003-04
University of Michigan
Peer Reviewer, National Science Foundation
Allan Schnaiberg Outstanding Publication Award
Committee
Member, 2014
Teaching Experience
Courses taught include:
Introduction to Sociology, Social Problems, Social Power and the Environment, Race, Class,
and Detroit, Social Inequality and Justice, Social Theory, Race & Ethnicity, Civic
Engagement, Service Learning & Leadership, Urban Sociology, Social Movements,
Masculinity, Asian-American Identity, Deviance, Environmental Justice, Law and Society,
Environmental Sociology, Political Sociology
